messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:55): never knew that commenting on a spec could be so fraught with difficulties
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:56): Looks like there's been more comments commenting on the process of commenting on the MathML spec, than there were comments on the spec
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:59): Hmm, it seems like someone has checked in RDFa support to MediaWiki.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:59): What does "support" mean?

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:00): RDFa attributes on elements seem to be whitelisted in user input.  Although I haven't looked very hard: http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:Code/MediaWiki/58712
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:00): I'm not sure this actually allows valid RDFa to be output, since it's not namespaced or anything?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:01): Valid RDFa? It relies upon namespaces, how can it be valid when it relies upon a DTD? :)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:01): Conformant RDFa, if you like.  I didn't mean valid in the XML sense.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:02): I know what you mean, but I'm just being silly about the whole problem with validity and RDFa :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:03): "RDFa properties allow URIs" - um, no they don't
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:04): (except about and resource)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:04): (which don't allow only URIs)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:06): Also: using a regep to detect 'unsafe' attribute values that might run scripts?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:06): *regexp
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:06): Yes, I commented on that separately.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:07): html5lib's sanitizer does that too
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:07): MediaWiki already has a whitelist of safe URL protocols, that should be used if anything is.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:07): Regex is fine, just it needs to be whitelist-based, not blacklist.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:07): That's assuming any of these URLs can actually be activated by the user, though, which I doubt.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:10): http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/#rdfa-attributes lists what the attributes are meant to contain
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:10): Well, the implementation basically allows any contents.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:10): The comment is misleading.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:11): My question is, does this actually allow conformant RDFa documents to be generated?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:11): I'm not sure.  You don't need namespace declarations or other fancy stuff?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:11): You do need namespace declarations
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:11): Where does it say that?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:11): Most of the stuff uses CURIEs, which require you to declare prefixes
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:11): They just make RDFa 120% more sexy.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:12): It seems like CURIEs are optional, you can just use the full URL if you feel like it?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:12): You can't (except in about and resource)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:12): You can only use the full URL if you have e.g., xmlns:http="http:"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:12): Can you give me a link to that in the spec so I can object properly?  :)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:12): This is freaking long.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:12): http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/#P_curie
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:12): is the syntax for CURIEs
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:13): which applies to rel/rev/property/datatype/typeof attributes
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:14): RDFa is a wonderly well-designed.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:14): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/#col_Metainformation says the meta attribs must (mostly) use curies
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:14): property="http://..." will get interpreted as a prefix "http" and reference "//..."
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:14): and not as a proper URL

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:16): The script-detection thing seems both useless (browsers aren't going to execute the URLs identified by RDFa attributes) and insufficient (if browsers did execute them, you could write <div xmlns:foo="jav" foo:property="ascript:alert('oops')">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:17): That's totally wrong
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:17): <div xmlns:foo="jav" property="foo:ascript:alert('oops')">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:17): (perhaps with more percent-encoding to be strictly legal)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:19): To allow microdata, we'd just have to permit the item* attributes, right?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:24): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: An unrelated probably bug: Looks like the code is trying to filter 'bad' rel/rev values, but rel/rev aren't allowed by the attribute whitelist anyway so that's pointless
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:24): *probable
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:25): Anyway, the xmlns: thing kind of kills it unless you only want to use prefixes that are already declared in the page template
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:25): We could whitelist xmlns:* if we really wanted to.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:25): I, of course, will argue we should support microdata instead.  :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:26): Why "of course"?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:26): Why not "of course"?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:26): I'm not sure why we need either, actually.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:26): He didn't give a reason.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:26): is also trying to persuade someone in #wikimedia-tech to turn on HTML5 output for Wikipedia already, but they all claim they want to go to sleep
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:26): (maybe tomorrow)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:28): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Why support a new and largely untested technology with precisely zero consumer support, like microdata?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:29): </body><title>foo</title> creates the title in the body element, right?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:29): Why support RDFa if it might die to microdata?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:29): Why support any of this stuff?  I'm not sure what the use-case is for us.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:29): I don't think you should support either :-)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:29): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Go look at that for me.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:29): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: No
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:30): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Pretty please?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:30): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: With a cherry on top?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:30): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Seems better to argue against RDFa due to lack of justification of the complexity it'll introduce
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:31): See, I don't know why he's introducing it at all.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (01:31): Hi everyone! \o/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:32): rather than due to a preference for microdata
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:32): Argh, stop being so happy >:-(
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:32): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I don't like cherries

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:34): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: (By "complexity" I suppose I'm thinking of the complexity of trying to support it properly, rather than badly hacking in a few attributes into a whitelist, though I'm not really sure what "properly" would mean)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:34): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, the support here is just letting people add it, i.e., not stripping it out as unrecognized.  Not very complicated.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:38): thinks one of zcorpan's tests is wrong
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:38): blames zcorpan
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:38): <script><!--<script --></script> --- how much of that is script contents?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:39): html5lib and me agree that the content is <!--<script -->
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:45): http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:Code/MediaWiki/58712#c4406
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:49): Hmm, looks like the use-case might be something like outputting EXIF data for images in structured format, stuff like that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:49): That could be legitimate.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:49): Meaning we would have to actually make a decision on RDFa vs. microdata.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (01:52): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, I'm sorry for being so happy.  I'll be more sad, just for you.
70bfd0ae2cfbf2da192bddd569cf6132 (01:52): moans because he never feels secure using the <section> tag.
